suggested_resources.topic: Introduction to Longevity Science & Historical Milestones (C. elegans, Kenyon, Sinclair, Cuervo)

book.title: Lifespan: Why We Age—and Why We Don't Have To
book.author: David A. Sinclair, Matthew D. LaPlante
book.reason: A readable overview by a prominent longevity researcher that connects historical discoveries (including genetic work in model organisms) to current ambitions and debates in the field; suitable as an accessible introduction for undergraduate students.

podcast.title: Science Vs — 'Can We Stop Aging?' (Episode)
podcast.reason: A journalistically-minded episode that summarizes key discoveries, controversies, and personalities in aging research in an approachable format for non-experts (look for their aging-related episodes or specials).

article.title: Genetics of ageing in Caenorhabditis elegans: insights from the age-1 and daf-2 pathways
article.reason: A clear review for students that explains the pivotal molecular genetic discoveries in C. elegans (including age-1/daf-2) and why they transformed thinking about aging from wear-and-tear to regulated biology.

suggested_resources.topic: Healthspan vs. Lifespan and Compression of Morbidity

book.title: The Telomere Effect: A Revolutionary Approach to Living Younger, Healthier, Longer
book.author: Elizabeth Blackburn and Elissa Epel
book.reason: Provides an evidence-based, accessible discussion of biological markers tied to healthspan (e.g., telomeres) alongside lifestyle factors that influence healthy aging — useful for students learning the distinction between lifespan and healthspan.

podcast.title: The Drive with Peter Attia — 'Healthspan vs Lifespan'
podcast.reason: Peter Attia frames the clinical and practical implications of prioritizing healthspan over mere life extension, offering a student-friendly conversation grounded in medical science.

article.title: The compression of morbidity hypothesis: a review of the evidence
article.reason: A scholarly review that traces James Fries' compression of morbidity idea and evaluates empirical support, helping students understand the population-health perspective on extending healthy years.

book.title: Ending Aging: The Rejuvenation Breakthroughs That Could Reverse Human Aging in Our Lifetime
book.author: Aubrey de Grey and Michael Rae
book.reason: Presents a framework-oriented, intervention-focused view of aging mechanisms and proposed repair strategies; provocative but useful for stimulating critical thinking about frameworks and goals in longevity science.

podcast.title: Huberman Lab Podcast — 'How and Why We Age' (episode with guest on aging biology)
podcast.reason: Translates key mechanistic concepts (DNA damage, proteostasis, telomeres, etc.) into clear explanations and practical takeaways suitable for undergraduates; look for episodes featuring aging researchers.

article.title: The Hallmarks of Aging (Cell, 2013) — López-Otín et al.
article.reason: The seminal, highly-cited paper that first articulated the hallmarks framework — essential reading for students to understand the standard taxonomy of aging mechanisms.

book.title: The Biology of Aging: Observations and Principles
book.author: Robert Arking
book.reason: A concise undergraduate-level textbook that covers cellular senescence among other aging processes, giving students foundational knowledge before diving into primary literature or translational studies.

podcast.title: Aging Research News — Interview with Judith Campisi on senescence
podcast.reason: A researcher-focused interview that explains senescent cell biology and the SASP in accessible terms and discusses translational prospects like senolytics.

article.title: Cellular senescence: a translational perspective
article.reason: A clear, up-to-date review in Nature Reviews Molecular Cell Biology that explains senescence mechanisms, systemic effects (SASP), and therapeutic strategies — suitable for motivated undergraduates.

book.title: Power, Sex, Suicide: Mitochondria and the Meaning of Life
book.author: Nick Lane
book.reason: An engaging, well-written exploration of mitochondrial biology and evolution that contextualizes why mitochondrial function matters for health and aging in a way that is both accessible and intellectually rich.

podcast.title: The Life Scientific — Episode with Douglas Wallace (mitochondrial genetics)
podcast.reason: An interview with a foundational mitochondrial geneticist that helps students grasp how mitochondrial DNA and dysfunction relate to disease and aging.

article.title: Mitophagy and mitochondrial quality control mechanisms in ageing and disease
article.reason: A focused review on mitophagy and mitochondrial quality control that connects molecular mechanisms to aging phenotypes and potential interventions like urolithin A.

suggested_resources.topic: Measuring Biological Age: Epigenetic Clocks and Biomarkers

book.title: The Epigenetics Revolution: How Modern Biology Is Rewriting Our Understanding of Genetics, Disease, and Inheritance
book.author: Nessa Carey
book.reason: An accessible primer on epigenetic concepts (including DNA methylation) that prepares students to understand how epigenetic clocks work without requiring deep prior knowledge.

podcast.title: The Peter Attia Drive — Episode with Steve Horvath on epigenetic clocks
podcast.reason: A deep but approachable discussion with the developer of the first multi-tissue epigenetic clock; useful for students wanting to hear the methods and implications explained by an expert.

article.title: DNA methylation-based biomarkers and the epigenetic clock theory of ageing
article.reason: A clear review that explains how epigenetic clocks were developed, their predictive power, limitations, and relevance for measuring biological age in research and clinical contexts.

suggested_resources.topic: Pillars of Intervention: Diet, Exercise, and Pharmacology (CR, fasting, exercise biology)

book.title: The Longevity Diet
book.author: Valter Longo
book.reason: A practical, science-informed guide to dietary strategies (including caloric restriction and fasting-mimicking diets) with references to the underlying research — appropriate for students exploring translational lifestyle interventions.

podcast.title: FoundMyFitness — 'Fasting, Longevity, and the Science of Diet' (episode with Valter Longo)
podcast.reason: An evidence-focused interview that discusses calorie restriction, fasting-mimicking diets, and mechanisms linking nutrition to aging in accessible language.

article.title: Calorie restriction and aging: a life-history analysis
article.reason: A readable review that synthesizes evidence for caloric restriction across species, its effects on lifespan and healthspan, and mechanistic explanations suitable for an introductory course.

suggested_resources.topic: Rapamycin, mTOR Pathway, and Pharmacological Geroprotection

book.title: The Molecule of More: How a Single Chemical in Your Brain Drives Love, Sex, and Creativity—and Will Determine the Fate of the Human Race
book.author: Daniel Z. Lieberman and Michael E. Long
book.reason: While not strictly about rapamycin/mTOR, this book offers an accessible introduction to how single molecular pathways can shape behavior and physiology; useful as a conceptual bridge before reading technical material on mTOR.

podcast.title: The Drive with Peter Attia — 'Rapamycin: A Deep Dive' (episode with Matt Kaeberlein)
podcast.reason: A detailed, practitioner-focused conversation with a leader in rapamycin research that explains the biology, preclinical data, dosing questions, and translational challenges in student-friendly terms.

article.title: mTOR signaling in growth, metabolism, and disease
article.reason: A comprehensive review of mTOR biology and its links to aging and disease; valuable for students who want a rigorous but readable synthesis of why targeting mTOR (e.g., with rapamycin) is promising.

suggested_resources.topic: Emerging Frontiers: Cellular Reprogramming, AI in Longevity, and Ethics

book.title: Regenesis: How Synthetic Biology Will Reinvent Nature and Ourselves
book.author: George M. Church and Ed Regis
book.reason: Provides accessible context about cutting-edge biotechnology (including reprogramming and synthetic biology) and its societal implications — helpful for students to place rejuvenation strategies in a broader technological and ethical frame.

podcast.title: The Ezra Klein Show — 'The Ethics and Promise of Radical Life Extension' (guest episodes on longevity and ethics)
podcast.reason: Features thoughtful discussions about the societal and ethical dimensions of life-extension technologies, useful for classroom debates and reflection.

article.title: In vivo partial reprogramming alters age-associated molecular changes and rejuvenates cells
article.reason: A high-profile experimental paper showing partial cellular reprogramming effects in mice — directly relevant to students learning about the promise and limits of reprogramming as an anti-aging strategy.

suggested_resources.topic: Translational & Societal Issues: Clinical Trials, Regulation, and Access (TAME, FDA debates)

book.title: Aging: The Longevity Dividend
book.author: edited by S. Jay Olshansky, George M. Martin, and others (selected chapters)
book.reason: A collection that includes policy, demographic, and clinical perspectives on aging interventions and their societal impacts — useful for students to connect lab findings to public health and regulation.

podcast.title: Science Magazine Podcast — 'Targeting Aging: the TAME trial and regulatory challenges'
podcast.reason: Covers the TAME trial and broader regulatory questions about treating aging as an indication, providing accessible reporting on a key translational effort.

article.title: Targeting aging with metformin: from trials to mechanisms (TAME trial overview)
article.reason: An explanatory article about the TAME trial that contextualizes scientific rationale, trial design, and regulatory implications — ideal for students learning how research moves toward clinical acceptance.
